text: If I solve an ODE without specifying the algorithm (it ends up using Vern9 and Rodas5) and I check the sol.t array I see that the timestep chosen is basically constant. If I then take this timestep and use it as the dt in an RODE problem solving with Euler I get huge numerical errors, I require a timestep that is ~1000 times smaller to see the same solution. I'd like some help understanding what's going on

elements.text: If I solve an ODE without specifying the algorithm (it ends up using Vern9 and Rodas5) and I check the sol.t array I see that the timestep chosen is basically constant. If I then take this timestep and use it as the dt in an RODE problem solving with Euler I get huge numerical errors, I require a timestep that is ~1000 times smaller to see the same solution. text: how are you using Vern9 and Rodas5 with RODE?

elements.text: how are you using Vern9 and Rodas5 with RODE?

text: Sorry I can try to be a bit clearer

elements.text: Sorry I can try to be a bit clearer

text: So if I pose my problem as an ODE and use Vern and Rodas to solve it then I can look at the time step they use. If I then change my problem to an RODE (or rather I just use a fixed time step solver for the ODE) and I set the fixed time step to the value that I got from Vern/Rodas I get huge numerical errors

elements.text: So if I pose my problem as an ODE and use Vern and Rodas to solve it then I can look at the time step they use. If I then change my problem to an RODE (or rather I just use a fixed time step solver for the ODE) and I set the fixed time step to the value that I got from Vern/Rodas I get huge numerical errors

text: yes, I'm not surprised. Euler has a lot more error, and RODEs amplify that. If you have Ito noise, it only converges like O(dt^(1/2)), while Vern9 converges like O(dt^9)

elements.text: yes, I'm not surprised. Euler has a lot more error, and RODEs amplify that. If you have Ito noise, it only converges like O(dt^(1/2)), while Vern9 converges like O(dt^9)

text: that's a full 18x difference in the exponent for the rate at which error drops!

elements.text: that's a full 18x difference in the exponent for the rate at which error drops!

text: so using the ODE is not a good starting point for the RODE

elements.text: so using the ODE is not a good starting point for the RODE

text: Okay that’s basically what I saw, I just wanted to make sure. I had to change my time step in the RODE by a factor of 10^4 to see the same solution

text: That's why I keep working on random ODEs and stochastic ODEs: there's a lot of work to be done because all of the methods are bad. Doing "good" is just "not doing horribly bad"
